title: Dele Alli speaks out on his controversial goal against Watford
text:
Dele Alli scored Tottenham’s equaliser in their 1-1 draw with Watford (Picture: Getty)

Dele Alli admitted the relief was tangible after his controversial goal against Watford was allowed to stand.

The England international salvaged a point for struggling Tottenham with his first strike since January, but confusion was abound when VAR appeared to have ruled out his effort for a handball offence.

Alli’s 86th minute strike was reviewed but referee Chris Kavanagh, who signalled for a goal only for the big screen to indicate it had been ruled out.

‘Of course it’s a relief,’ said Alli after his goal was eventually given the green light.

‘There were two times he [the referee] stopped it when he was making the decisions. We weren’t sure why.

VAR appeared to have ruled out Dele Alli’s goal against Watford (Picture: Getty)

‘I was sure it didn’t hit my hand but then you start thinking did it? I tried to make sure it didn’t touch it so I could get the strike away.’

The point kept Spurs within three points of fourth place Arsenal, who visit Sheffield United on Monday evening, and Alli is hopeful his goal could prove the turning point in his side’s season.

He added: ‘We made it difficult for ourselves. We controlled the game and bossed possession.

‘It was my first start and great to be back in the team but overall a disappointing result.

‘We know we have a world-class team so it’s about showing what we can do when things don’t go our way.

‘It’s important we turn it around. We know how good we are, we just have to start showing it on the pitch.’
